item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #656 (siteurl option can be changed by users when host has multiple names) created
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description:
<a href="â€‹http://weblog.burningbird.net/archives/2004/12/03/kitchen-was-hacked/">Burningbird writes about it</a>. Although it's not broken any more, it still will switch the siteurl option when the user accesses wp-login.php with a different site name from the original name. If your site has multiple server aliases, the primary name can be switched by remote users without any previous login.

I think this option fixing needs to go into some intermediate page that requires the admin password to proceed.

item.title: Ticket #587 (Comments RSS shows latest entry url as itemlink for all items) updated
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description:
It can be fixed by applying the following fix:

RCS file: /cvsroot/cafelog/wordpress/wp-commentsrss2.php,v retrieving revision 1.23 diff -u -r1.23 wp-commentsrss2.php --- wp-commentsrss2.php 14 Dec 2004 09:48:34 -0000 1.23 +++ wp-commentsrss2.php 10 Jan 2005 20:37:03 -0000 @@ -44,6 +44,7 @@

this line is WordPress' motor, do not delete it.

if ($comments) {

foreach ($comments as $comment) {

+ $post = $wpdb->get_row("SELECT * FROM $wpdb->posts WHERE ID = '$comment->comment_post_ID'");

?>

<item>

<title>by: <?php comment_author_rss() ?></title>

This is rather crude, though, as it pulls in the post for every comment, even if the post was already fetched by some former comment. But at least it now provides correct links, as the comment_link_rss and get_comments_link (actually get_permalink) all rely on some $post set to the current post from the loop.

edited on: 01-10-05 20:37

item.title: Ticket #654 (metaWeblogAPI.newMediaObject fails on file writing) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #654 (metaWeblogAPI.newMediaObject fails on file writing) updated
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #654 (metaWeblogAPI.newMediaObject fails on file writing) created
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description:
The newMediaObject call failes when sending files with ecto to Wordpress. The reason is a bug in class-IXR.php where the base64_decode call (at least with PHP 4.1.something) failes to decode stuff. The string that is passed on to the base64_decode call must be trimmed. A patch is:

diff -r1.3 class-IXR.php 227c227 < $value = base64_decode($this->_currentTagContents); ---

$value = base64_decode(trim($this->_currentTagContents));

item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description:
A cursory search through the PHP 4 Changelog (â€‹http://www.php.net/ChangeLog-4.php) doesn't appear to show any require_once() bugfixes since my PHP version (4.2.2).

Ryan: What PHP version are you running, and on what platform?

item.title: Ticket #649 (Custom 'Options' pages for plugins display duplicate content) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: I meant the require_once on admin.php from the various admin pages. I cannot reproduce with any of the plugins that add admin pages, including Spaminator. I'll look around some more.

item.title: Ticket #649 (Custom 'Options' pages for plugins display duplicate content) updated
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description:
[Kitten:] Ok, you've found a Safari bug most likely. Firefox on linux does not do that. Don't know what to do about it, since I don't have a Mac. Another thought, do a fresh CVS checkout in another directory, and install spaminator and see if it still does it.

I've attached plugin-options-screenshot-4.png, a picture of the same behavior in Firefox 1.0 on a fresh CVS install.

[rboren:] Very odd. Sounds like require_once() is not doing its job, or something.

The code that inserts the content in question uses only include(), not include_once() or require_once() (see lines 55 and 57 of wp-admin/admin.php). Apparently somehow with the cyclical dependencies those are in fact being executed twice.

Are you able to reproduce this issue, Ryan?

item.title: Ticket #649 (Custom 'Options' pages for plugins display duplicate content) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Very odd. Sounds like require_once() is not doing its job, or something.

item.description: Attached another screenshot (plugin-options-screenshot-3.png) showing Spaminator (the latest version) exhibiting the behavior in question.

item.title: Ticket #649 (Custom 'Options' pages for plugins display duplicate content) updated
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description: One additional note: admin-footer.php is duplicated as well. It's not just the plugin content.

item.title: Ticket #649 (Custom 'Options' pages for plugins display duplicate content) updated
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description:
Status, Resolution changed

Kitten: That's not the issue this bug refers to. (I corrected that in my local copy of Spaminator as soon as I saw it, but I should've probably mentioned it in Steps to Reproduce above.) You fixed something different.

This bug refers to the duplication of content on the Options pages. I updated to your new revision of Spaminator (which made the same change I did previously to my local copy), and this bug is still present.

I think you'll find that this is in fact an issue with WordPress, and cannot be fixed by changing the plugin itself. This issue would appear to be caused by cyclical includes between admin.php and admin-header.php.

See the screenshots attached to this bug for a visual illustration of the bug.

Reopening.

item.title: Ticket #649 (Custom 'Options' pages for plugins display duplicate content) closed
item.dc:creator: Kitten

item.title: Ticket #649 (Custom 'Options' pages for plugins display duplicate content) updated
item.dc:creator: Kitten
item.description:
I've updated spaminator (rev. 174) to "work around" this problem, by wrapping the problem call in a "! function_exists" wrapper.

Basically this is happening because the plugins are loaded by WP's core, then the plugin file itself is called again to show the page. It wouldn't be a problem if I wanted to make the admin page a seperate file. But that would make it a more complicated install, and 2 files to version, etc.

The function_exists trade off is inelegant, but suitable in this instance.

In the future, problems of this nature should be reported in the plugins repository, ( â€‹http://dev.wp-plugins.org/newticket ) because it is a plugin bug not a WP issue.

I'm going to close this bug, if the reporter concurs, he can resolve it.

edited on: 01-10-05 02:53

item.dc:creator: morganiq

item.title: Ticket #649 (Custom 'Options' pages for plugins display duplicate content) updated
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description:
[2fargon:] Maybe the plugins need to be updated to conform to the change in the scheme of things.

I'm not sure which way you mean this, because #393 relates to plugins that need to be updated as well. But if you mean that the plugins I mention above under Steps to Reproduce should be changed to fix this issue, there's no way the plugins themselves can correct this behavior; it has to be corrected within WordPress. The change I mentioned in my previous bugnote was what caused the behavior, but I'm sure Ryan or Kitten can come up with a fix that will solve both this issue and #393 satisfactorily.

[2fargon:] Can you contact the plugin authors please?

Were you talking to me with this? 'Cause Kitten's one of 'em, and she's been assigned this bug. I can contact Owen if you want, but like I said, he can't do anything to correct this issue within the plugin itself.

item.title: Ticket #587 (Comments RSS shows latest entry url as itemlink for all items) updated
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description:
This could be fixed if the following functions could accept arguments:

comment_link_rss($comment_ID) get_comments_link($comment_ID, $post_ID = FALSE)

I've chosen comment IDs instead of post IDs since it seems to me comment_link_rss should reference #comment-IDnumber rather than #comments. get_comments_link could still return #comments if passed a post ID.

item.title: Ticket #646 (Broken Codex link in 'Edit Permalink Structure' section) updated
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description:
What do you mean by " be corrected in WordPress rather than just setting up a redirect " ?

Apologies, I thought I had been explicit enough. I would prefer that the actual hyperlink on the WordPress Admin page be changed to reflect the new Codex page title, rather than simply setting up a redirect in Codex to forward links from the old page title to the new page title. That's why I submitted a diff.

I got the impression that the Codex pages linked-to from WordPress should be prevented from being renamed - which is what has been done.

That is what I meant, mostly -- except that I had pictured changing the link in WordPress and then protecting Using_Permalinks from being moved, but without preventing it from being edited, if it is possible to do so.

edited on: 01-09-05 17:31

item.title: Ticket #646 (Broken Codex link in 'Edit Permalink Structure' section) updated
item.dc:creator: 2fargon
item.description:
According to the bug report you filed, which said: "Description 'number of tags are available' links to â€‹http://codex.wordpress.org/Permalink_Structure, [] which no longer exists. The page has since been renamed to Using_Permalinks, and the redirect was deleted in maintenance. Additional Information Perhaps those Codex pages that are linked to from within WP should be prevented from being renamed."

I got the impression that the Codex pages linked-to from WordPress should be prevented from being renamed - which is what has been done.

What do you mean by " be corrected in WordPress rather than just setting up a redirect " ?

Please be explicit is stating what the problem is. Problems may not always be resolved in the way expected.

As the codex matures, the links to codex pages from WordPress will get corrected. A number of web-pages linked to from within version 1.2 are no longer linked to -- so things change all the time.

item.title: Ticket #649 (Custom 'Options' pages for plugins display duplicate content) updated
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description:
Patch changed
  1. Download and install Kitten's Spaminator â€‹http://dev.wp-plugins.org/file/spaminator/trunk/kittens-spaminator.php?rev=168&format=txt and/or Geo â€‹http://dev.wp-plugins.org/file/geo/trunk/geo.php?rev=102&format=txt
  2. Remove the last newline in each to eliminate "Headers already sent" errors, then activate the plugins.
  3. In the Admin panel, click 'Options' from the menu, then 'Geo Info' and/or 'Spaminator' from the submenu

item.title: Ticket #649 (Custom 'Options' pages for plugins display duplicate content) created
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description:
The 'Options' pages of plugins such as Kitten's Spaminator and Geo (which are the only plugins I know of at the moment that use custom Options pages) display duplicates of:

  • The custom page content generated by the plugin.
  • The custom submenu item for the plugin.

Note that the custom submenu item is only duplicated when a plugin Options page is selected. However, if other plugins are installed, their submenu items are duplicated as well.

item.title: Ticket #647 (staticize_header() non-functional) updated
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Stanley
item.description:
Patch changed

1: Install WP 2: Enable Staticized 3: Function is broken, noted by the conspicuous absense of "X-Staticize" timer... therefore makes contextual MIME setting within that function broken

item.title: Ticket #647 (staticize_header() non-functional) created
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Stanley
item.description:
The header that's supposed to be sent by this function never is, meaning all cached files will only ever be sent with the MIME type "text/html" which is of no use to the anally rententive XHTML crowd/those that use XHTML1.1 properly.

Also, it effected some builds of WP1.3 (IIRC a5), the feeds... as those were caching (1.5 doesn't seem to do this anymore?) and meant their XML-ness with more compliant parsers was completely lost as they too were sent with the incorrect MIME type of "text/html".

item.title: Ticket #636 (Post time display error) closed
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
20:

â€‹http://wordpress.org/pipermail/cvs/2005-January/000861.html
